title: Milner–Rado paradox
summary: In set theory, a branch of mathematics, the Milner – Rado paradox, found by Eric Charles Milner and Richard Rado (1965), states that every ordinal number α {\displaystyle \alpha } less than the successor κ + {\displaystyle \kappa ^{+}} of some cardinal number κ {\displaystyle \kappa } can be written as the union of sets X 1 , X 2 , . . . {\displaystyle X_{1},X_{2},...} where X n {\displaystyle X_{n}} is of order type at most κn for n a positive integer.
